newsitem.title: JAPAN: Tokyo Nikkei seen stalling around 20,000.
newsitem.headline: Tokyo Nikkei seen stalling around 20,000.

text.p: The Tokyo stock market's key index is likely to hover around 20,000 on Friday, as the buying of major export-oriented issues that led the recent rally will be cooled by the yen's advance against the dollar, brokers said.
But investors are expected to hunt for bargains in other blue-chip issues whose gains have lagged, and this is likely to keep the downside solid, they said.
On Thursday, the 225-share Nikkei average rose 12.91 points or 0.06 percent to close at 20,061.81. June Nikkei futures were down 20 points at 20,060.
"Investors will hesitate to chase export-oriented issues due to the yen's surge," said Yasuo Ueki, general manager at Nikko Securities Co Ltd.
The dollar fell sharply overnight. It traded at around 123.50 yen in early Asia trade on Friday, down over one yen from 124.85/95 in late Tokyo trade on Thursday.
The currency movements will somewhat offset a psychological support factor, which is the strength in U.S. stocks, brokers said.
On Thursday, the Dow industrials finished up 51 points at 7,137.
But investor demand is expected to remain firm below the major 20,000 level on the Nikkei 225, with foreign investors especially interested in buying blue-chip laggard issues, brokers said.
They said the focus would be shares in Sony Corp, which announced late on Thursday that its parent current profit for 1996/97 had tripled from the previous year to 85.73 billion yen.
